Description: PURPOSE: TO CONDUCT RESEARCH ON FALSE KILLER WHALES AROUND HAWAII TO INFORM THE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN FALSE KILLER WHALES AND FISHERIES. THIS RESEARCH IS INTENDED TO HELP REDUCE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN FALSE KILLER WHALES AND FISHERS AND TO UNDERSTAND WHALE DEMOGRAPHICS, ABUNDANCE, AND MOVEMENT PATTERNS. THIS PROJECT HAS FOUR MAIN OBJECTIVES: 1. TO OBTAIN AND ANALYZE DATA FROM PELAGIC FALSE KILLER WHALES TO INFORM MITIGATION MEASURES TO REDUCE FISHERY INTERACTIONS. THIS WILL INCLUDE SATELLITE TAGGING AND ANALYSIS OF SATELLITE TAG DATA TO: 1) BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW PELAGIC GROUPS INTERACT WITH LONGLINE GEAR (THROUGH ANALYSES OF TAG, LOGBOOK, AND OBSERVER PROGRAM DATA); AND 2) TO DETERMINE WHAT FACTORS (E.G., EDDY SYSTEMS) PROMOTE THE CO-OCCURRENCE OF PELAGIC FALSE KILLER WHALES, THEIR PREY, AND FISHING VESSELS BOTH IN THE UNITED STATES, AND FOREIGN FLEETS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO ASSESS NEW PHOTOS FOR EVIDENCE OF FISHERY INTERACTIONS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW THE LIKELIHOOD OF INTERACTING WI

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DEVELOP A BYCATCH REDUCTION DEVICE (BRD) PERFORMANCE INDICATOR (BPI) TO EVALUATE AND COMPARE BRDS USED IN THE BERING SEA PACIFIC COD BOTTOM TRAWL FISHERY, EVALUATE THE EFFECT OF ARTIFICIAL LIGHT (USED AS A BRD) PLACED AT THE TRAWL MOUTH ON PACIFIC HALIBUT AND PACIFIC COD CATCH THROUGH FIELD TRIAL, AND APPLY THE BPI TO EVALUATE CURRENT AND PREVIOUSLY ATTEMPTED BRDS FOR THIS FISHERY AND COMPARE TO THE USE OF ARTIFICIAL LIGHT. RESULTS OF THIS RESEARCH WILL BE USED TO MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS TO FISHERIES RESEARCHERS, MANAGERS, AND THE FISHING INDUSTRY ON BRD USE AND/OR NEXT STEPS IN BRD DEVELOPMENT.

THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE HOOK SIZE, AND APPENDAGE ANGLE AND POSITION TO REDUCE YELLOWEYE ROCKFISH AND PACIFIC SPINY DOGFISH BYCATCH IN A PACIFIC HALIBUT LONGLINE FISHERY. BEHAVIOR OF HALIBUT, YELLOWEYE ROCKFISH, AND PACIFIC SPINY DOGFISH AS THEY INTERACT WITH DIFFERENT CIRCLE HOOK SIZES WILL BE STUDIED, AND SEA TRIALS WILL BE CONDUCTED TO TEST HOOK DESIGN.

THIS STUDY AIMS TO REFINE EFFECTIVE METHODS FOR PROTECTING LONGLINE CAPTURED FISH FROM DEPREDATION AND TO COMPLETE REPLICATES IN THE PRESENCE OF TOOTHED WHALES IN KNOWN DEPREDATION HOTSPOTS TO DEMONSTRATE THE EFFICACY AND SAFETY OF THE GEAR. THE PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE PERFORMANCE OF CATCH PROTECTION DEVICES TO EFFECTIVELY REDUCE DEPREDATION OF LONGLINE CAPTURED FISH IN THE PRESENCE OF TOOTHED WHALES, AND ASSESS THE PERFORMANCE METRICS OF CATCH PROTECTION DEVICES ON THE SIZE, NUMBER, AND CONDITION OF FISH SUCCESSFULLY ENTRAINED IN THE DEVICES.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO EMPLOY A GLOBAL SYNTHESIS USING A BAYESIAN MULTILEVEL NETWORK META-ANALYTIC MODELING FRAMEWORK, TO DETERMINE WHETHER ALTERNATIVE BRANCHLINE WEIGHTING DESIGNS DEFINED IN BINDING MEASURES OF REGIONAL FISHERIES MANAGEMENT ORGANIZATIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE AGREEMENT ON THE CONSERVATION OF ALBATROSSES AND PETRELS CAUSE SIGNIFICANTLY DIFFERENT SEABIRD CATCH RATES, AND WHETHER THESE PRESCRIBED DESIGNS PRODUCE SIGNIFICANTLY DIFFERENT SEABIRD BYCATCH RATES THAN OTHER BRANCHLINE WEIGHTING DESIGNS USED IN GLOBAL PELAGIC LONGLINE FISHERIES. THE STUDY WILL IDENTIFY INFORMATIVE PREDICTORS OF SEABIRD CATCH RISK OTHER THAN BRANCHLINE WEIGHTING. A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW WILL BE CONDUCTED TO COMPILE RELEVANT PUBLICATIONS AND ASSEMBLE A DATASET SUITABLE FOR THE META-ANALYTIC EVALUATION.

THIS PROJECT HAS FIVE MAIN OBJECTIVES TO ENCOURAGE THE UPTAKE OF A PROVEN NET DESIGN TO REDUCE ATLANTIC COD (GADUS MORHUA) BY 46%: 1. ESTABLISH A MULTISTAKEHOLDER GROUP OF STRATEGIC ADVISORS COMPOSED OF FISHERS, NET MAKERS, RESEARCHERS, AND A SCIENTIFIC COMMUNICATIONS SPECIALIST, 2. EQUIP FIVE VESSELS WITH ULOT NETS FOR COMMERCIAL USE AND RESEARCH PURPOSES, 3. OBTAIN QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE INFORMATION ON NET USE, FUEL CONSUMPTION, AND CATCH COMPOSITION, 4. PROVIDE OUTREACH TO OTHER INDUSTRY MEMBERS AND INDUSTRY PUBLICATIONS FOR INCREASED UPTAKE, AND 5. PROVIDE OUTREACH TO THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY ON THE EFFICACY OF A HIGHLY INCENTIVIZED UPTAKE STRATEGY AS A CHANGE MANAGEMENT MODEL.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE PROVIDING A PATHWAY TOWARD THE COMMERCIAL IMPLEMENTATION OF ON-DEMAND GEAR ON THE US EAST COAST PROJECT TO REDUCE BYCATCH OF THE NORTH ATLANTIC RIGHT WHALE POPULATION. OBJECTIVES INCLUDE TRAINING UP TO 100 PARTICIPANTS, ENHANCING THE GEAR AVAILABLE IN THE GEAR CACHE WAREHOUSE TO LOAN TO AS MANY PARTICIPANTS AS POSSIBLE, PROVIDING INDUSTRY FEEDBACK TO MANUFACTURERS TO IMPROVE GEAR PERFORMANCE, CONDUCTING TRIALS OF A CLOUD-BASED DIGITAL MARKING SYSTEM WITH FIXED AND MOBILE GEAR FISHERIES, COMPARING DATA USING GEAR FROM A VARIETY OF MANUFACTURERS IN DIFFERENT WATER DEPTHS, WATER TEMPERATURES, SPEEDS OF TIDES, AND TYPE OF OCEAN BOTTOM, AND REACHING 1500 MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC THROUGH IN-PERSON AND/OR VIRTUAL ON-DEMAND GEAR DEMONSTRATIONS, AND PROMOTE DIVERSITY, EQUITY, AND INCLUSION IN MARINE SCIENCE AND CONSERVATION.

THE PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO ADVANCE THE REQUIRED TESTING AND DEVELOPMENT OF PREVIOUSLY PILOTED POUND NET TECHNOLOGY IN THE LOWER COLUMBIA RIVER EMERGING COMMERCIAL FISHERY. TWO POUND NETS WILL BE PURCHASED AND IMPLEMENTED. THIS WILL ENABLE COMMERCIAL FISHING AS WELL AS PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE TO CONDUCT THEIR EVALUATION OF THE NETS.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ESTABLISH INTERNATIONAL COLLABORATIONS BETWEEN MEXICAN LONG-LINE FISHERS, RESEARCHERS, AND MANAGERS TO ASSESS OPTIONS FOR INCREASING LONGLINE GEAR SELECTIVITY IN MEXICO,  DOCUMENT FISHERY OPERATIONS AND CHARACTERIZE THE SHALLOW-SET FISHERY FOR SHARKS AND SWORDFISH OPERATING OFF NORTHERN BAJA CALIFORNIA, MEXICO, IDENTIFY WHICH US DEVELOPED SHARK MITIGATION TOOLS ALIGN WITH THE MEXICAN FLEET OPERATIONS, CONDUCT FIELD TESTING OF ARTIFICIAL BAITS AND MICRO-PROCESSOR BASED BYCATCH REDUCTION DEVICES ONBOARD MEXICAN LONGLINE VESSELS, EVALUATE PERFORMANCE, ECONOMIC FEASIBILITY, AND POTENTIAL FOR FUTURE USE BY THE MEXICAN LONGLINE INDUSTRY, GENERATE A BILINGUAL REPORT ON POTENTIAL MITIGATION OPTIONS, AND DISSEMINATE FINDINGS AND INSIGHTS THROUGH A BI-LINGUAL HANDBOOK AND COLLABORATIVE SCIENTIFIC MANUSCRIPT.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ESTIMATE THE POST-RELEASE MORTALITY FOR BLUE MARLIN CAPTURED IN PELAGIC LONGLINE FISHERIES IN THE GULF OF MEXICO, IDENTIFY THE INFLUENCE OF ENVIRONMENTAL (E.G., TEMPERATURE) AND CAPTURE-RELATED (E.G., TIME ON HOOK, DEPTH, HANDLING TIME, ETC.) VARIABLES CONTRIBUTING TO POST RELEASE MORTALITY OF BLUE MARLIN, AND CHARACTERIZE BYCATCH OF BLUE MARLIN ON PELAGIC LONGLINES DEPLOYED AT NORMAL VERSUS DEEP SET DEPTHS TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF DEEPER SET DEPTH AT TARGETING YELLOWFIN TUNA WHILE REDUCING BYCATCH OF BLUE MARLIN.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE NEEDED ROBUST ESTIMATES OF STRIPED BASS CATCH AND RELEASE MORTALITY (CRM), BY DEVELOPING A QUICK ATTACHMENT, DELAYED RELEASE ACOUSTIC TAG AND USE THIS METHOD IN SITU TO ESTIMATE CHESAPEAKE BAY STRIPED BASS CRM DURING SPRING AND SUMMER 2024. INVESTIGATORS WILL ALSO ESTIMATE THE RELATIONSHIP OF CRM WITH TEMPERATURE AND SHARE THESE ESTIMATES TO IMPROVE STOCK ASSESSMENT AND INFORM ADAPTABLE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO LIMIT STRIPED BASS FISHING IN ELEVATED WATER TEMPERATURES, THEREBY REDUCING CRM, WHILE INCREASING STOCK SIZE AND SUSTAINABILITY.

THIS PROJECT INTENDS TO INCREASE THE UNDERSTANDING OF FALSE KILLER WHALE (FKW) FORAGING BEHAVIOR IN RELATION TO PREY AND FISHING ACTIVITY, TO HELP INFORM STRATEGIES TO REDUCE DEPREDATION AND BYCATCH. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL TEST THE FOLLOWING HYPOTHESES: 1. LOCAL PHYSICAL OCEANOGRAPHIC CONDITIONS DRIVE DISTRIBUTIONS OF FKW PREY, 2. FKWS SENSE AND TARGET HIGH DENSITY OF PREY, AND 3. FKW REACT TO AND MODIFY THEIR FORAGING BEHAVIOR IN THE PRESENCE OF FISHING VESSELS.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE COVERAGE FOR AN ONGOING FISHERY-DEPENDENT AT-SEA OBSERVER SURVEY CONDUCTED BY THE FLORIDA FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION COMMISSION, IN COOPERATION WITH THE RECREATIONAL CHARTER AND HEADBOAT INDUSTRY ALONG THE NORTHEAST COAST OF FLORIDA. THIS PROGRAM EMPLOYS FISHERY OBSERVERS TO MONITOR FISHING PRACTICES USED TO HARVEST AND RELEASE IMPORTANT MANAGED REEF FISH SPECIES THAT ARE ENCOUNTERED IN THE FOR-HIRE RECREATIONAL HOOK-AND-LINE FISHERIES, CHARACTERIZE SPECIES COMPOSITIONS AND SIZE DISTRIBUTIONS OF RETAINED AND DISCARDED PORTIONS OF THE CATCH WITH RESPECT TO DEPTH AND LATITUDE, AND MONITOR SUBSEQUENT MOVEMENT AND MORTALITY OF DISCARDS FOLLOWING CATCH-AND-RELEASE THROUGH THE USE OF MARK-RECAPTURE METHODS. RECREATIONAL DISCARDS OF IMPORTANT MANAGED REEF FISH SPECIES ARE MARKED WITH CONVENTIONAL TAGS PRIOR TO RELEASE.
THE PROPOSED WORK WILL CONTINUE THEIR E-TAG RESEARCH PROGRAM BY CONDUCTING ACOUSTIC, ARCHIVAL AND SATELLITE TAGGING, MOVEMENT ECOLOGY, GENETIC STOCK IDENTIFICATION AND FISHERIES MODELING.
THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DEVELOP A NEXT-GENERATION STOCK ASSESSMENT MODEL FOR ATLANTIC BLUEFIN TUNA THAT MAY ALSO BE USED AS AN OPERATING MODEL FOR FUTURE MANAGEMENT STRATEGY EVALUATION (MSE) FRAMEWORKS.

THE PROPOSED WORK WILL CONTINUE A BIOLOGICAL SAMPLING PROGRAM AND USE THOSE SAMPLES TO ESTIMATE AGE, GROWTH, AND STOCK MIXING OF ABFT TO IMPROVE THE ASSESSMENT AND MANAGEMENT PROCESS FOR THIS FISHERY RESOURCE WHICH MAY INCLUDE THE ADOPTION OF A NEW MANAGEMENT STRATEGY EVALUATION STRUCTURE FOR THIS SPECIES.

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF KOTZEBUE'S PROJECT IN 2023 IS TO USE PASSIVE ACOUSTIC MONITORING TECHNIQUES TO INVESTIGATE THE YEAR-ROUND SPATIOTEMPORAL DISTRIBUTION OF BEARDED SEALS AND RINGED SEALS AND THEIR RELATIONSHIP TO ICE CONCENTRATION IN KOTZEBUE SOUND, ALASKA IN UP TO SIX SAMPLED AREAS. THIS PROJECT WILL BE THE FIRST DEDICATED PASSIVE ACOUSTIC MONITORING EFFORT TO MONITOR BEARDED SEALS AND RINGED SEALS IN KOTZEBUE SOUND, AND LAYS THE GROUND FOR FUTURE RESEARCH IN OTHER AREAS OF ALASKA. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH A SERIES OF ACTIVITIES CONDUCTED BY THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF KOTZEBUE'S ENVIRONMENTAL PROGRAM STAFF IN COORDINATION WITH THEIR PROPOSED CONSULTANT AND PROJECT INVESTIGATOR. THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE A COMBINATION OF FIELD, LABORATORY WORK, AND OUTREACH DESIGNED TO SET THE BASELINE NEEDED TO IDENTIFY CHANGES AND CHARACTERIZE TRENDS IN SEAL PRESENCE AND HABITAT USE IN RELATION TO ICE CONCENTRATIONS TO IMPROVE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF BEARDED AND RING

THE SHORTNOSE STURGEON, ACIPENSER BREVIROSTRUM, WAS ONCE ABUNDANT IN ALL MAJOR COASTAL RIVER SYSTEMS BUT NOW IS ONE OF THE MOST ENDANGERED MEMBERS OF THE STURGEON FAMILY. ACCORDING TO THE NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE FINAL RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE SHORTNOSE STURGEON (1998), A POPULATION IS THOUGHT TO INHABIT THE EDISTO RIVER, HOWEVER POPULATION DYNAMICS ARE COMPLETELY UNKNOWN. THE LACK OF DATA AND PRESENCE OF HATCHERY-REARED SHORTNOSE STURGEON FROM SAVANNAH RIVER HAVE CALLED INTO QUESTION THE EXISTENCE OF A NATIVE POPULATION IN THE EDISTO RIVER. OBJECTIVES OF THIS STUDY ARE TO PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION FOR SHORTNOSE STURGEON OF ALL LIFE STAGES WITH THE GOAL OF CONFIRMATION OF A NATIVE AND GENETICALLY DISTINCT POPULATION OF SHORTNOSE STURGEON IN THE EDISTO RIVER. METHODS WILL INCLUDE MARK-RECAPTURE VIA GILLNETTING, ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY, AND GENETIC ANALYSIS. THESE DATA WILL ADDRESS PRIORITY 1 TASKS IDENTIFIED IN THE RECOVERY PLAN, ALLOW FOR IMPROVED MANAGEMENT, AND AID IN RESTORING T

THIS PROGRAM IS EMBARKING ON THE NEXT PHASE OF RESTORATION FOR THE WHITE ABALONE (HALIOTIS SORENSENI) BY CONTINUING BIANNUAL PULSED STOCKING OF WHITE ABALONE INTO ESTABLISHED SITES AND WORKING TOWARDS EXPANDING STOCKING SITES TO MORE REMOTE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA LOCATIONS WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF STREAMLINED STOCKING METHODS. THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH & WILDLIFE INTENDS TO APPROACH THIS PHASE THROUGH THREE OBJECTIVES: 1) CONTINUE COLLABORATIVE ADAPTIVE BIANNUAL STOCKING OF CAPTIVE BRED WHITE AND RED ABALONE AT ESTABLISHED EXPERIMENTAL STOCKING SITES IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA; 2) CONDUCT RESEARCH TO OPTIMIZE AND IMPROVE WHITE ABALONE STOCKING SITE SELECTION; AND 3) CONTINUE COLLABORATIVE MONITORING OF WILD WHITE ABALONE POPULATIONS AND NATURAL RECRUITMENT TO LEARN AND ADAPT SUCCESSFUL STOCKING STRATEGIES. THESE EFFORTS WILL BE CONDUCTED IN COORDINATION WITH NOAA PROTECTED RESOURCES AND WILL LEVERAGE THE STRENGTHS OF ALL PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS TO PROMOTE HEALTHY SELF-SUSTAINING WILD

THIS PROJECT HAS BEEN DEVELOPED TO ASSESS THE POPULATION STATUS AND DISTRIBUTION OF ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT LISTED STONY CORAL SPECIES IN THE UNITED STATES VIRGIN ISLANDS AT A CRITICAL JUNCTURE AFTER THE APPEARANCE AND SEVERE NEGATIVE IMPACTS OF CARIBBEAN STONY CORAL TISSUE LOSS DISEASE. THIS PROJECT WILL (1) USE FIELD-TESTED STRATIFIED RANDOMIZED SYNOPTIC SURVEYS TO ACHIEVE ROBUST ESTIMATES OF SURVIVING POPULATIONS OF THREE SPECIES IN THE UNITED STATES VIRGIN ISLANDS (ACROPORA CERVICORNIS, ACROPORA PALMATA, AND DENDROGYRA CYLINDRUS), (2) CARRY OUT RESCUE OF EXTREMELY SUSCEPTIBLE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT CORAL SPECIES, AND (3) ENGAGE THE WIDER PUBLIC IN AWARENESS OF ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT LISTED STONY CORAL SPECIES THROUGH COMMUNITY OUTREACH. THIS PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN EXISTING AND ONGOING CORAL RESTORATION ACTIVITIES TARGETING ACORPORA AND D. CYLINDRUS, AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES TO PROMOTE ENGAGEMENT AND AWARENESS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO SUPPORT AND STRENGTHEN A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE L

FIN AND NORTH ATLANTIC RIGHT WHALES ENDURE NUMEROUS THREATS TO THEIR SURVIVAL, INCLUDING INJURY/DEATH CAUSED BY ENTANGLEMENT IN FISHING GEAR OR VESSEL STRIKES AS WELL AS NEGATIVE EFFECTS FROM CLIMATE CHANGE, ANTHROPOGENIC NOISE, AND POTENTIALLY OFFSHORE WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT. BOTH SPECIES ARE LISTED AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT, THEREFORE, MITIGATING THESE THREATS IS OF CRITICAL IMPORTANCE TO THEIR RECOVERY FROM COMMERCIAL WHALING. IN REGIONS, LIKE THE WATERS OF MAINE, OUR ABILITY TO MITIGATE THESE THREATS IS CONSTRAINED BY OUR LIMITED UNDERSTANDING OF NORTH ATLANTIC RIGHT WHALE AND FIN WHALE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DETERMINE FIN AND NORTH ATLANTIC RIGHT WHALE DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND DENSITY FOR THIS REGION USING DATA FROM SIMULTANEOUS PASSIVE ACOUSTIC MONITORING AND AERIAL SURVEYS. TO MEET THIS GOAL WE WILL ACCOMPLISH THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES: 1) COLLECT TWO YEARS OF PASSIVE ACOUSTIC MONITORING AND AERIAL SURVEY DATA, 2) ESTI

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO USE A COMBINATION OF GENETIC MIXED-STOCK ANALYSIS AND ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY TO INFORM POPULATION STRUCTURE OF ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT LISTED ATLANTIC STURGEON IN THE SOUTHERN EXTENT OF THEIR RANGE (WITHIN THE CAROLINA AND SOUTH ATLANTIC DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENTS). THE MAIN PROJECT GOAL WILL BE TO ESTIMATE THE EXTENT OF POPULATION MIXING WITHIN AND BETWEEN DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENTS FOR SUB-ADULT (600-1300 MM FL) ATLANTIC STURGEON, AS THIS LIFE HISTORY STAGE HAS DEMONSTRATED EXTENSIVE USE OF NON-NATAL RIVERS/ESTUARIES, WITH CONSIDERABLE MOVEMENTS OBSERVED AMONG SOUTHERN RIVERS. THE PROJECT WILL TAKE ADVANTAGE OF ARCHIVED TISSUE SAMPLES FROM SEVERAL MAJOR RIVER SYSTEMS IN THE CAROLINA AND SOUTH ATLANTIC DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENTS, AS WELL AS ESTABLISHED ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY ARRAYS TO TRACK SEASONAL AND ANNUAL MOVEMENTS OVER MULTIPLE YEARS. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO USE A COMBINATION OF GENETIC MIXED-STOCK ANALYSIS AND ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY TO INFORM POPULATION STRUCTURE OF ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT LISTED ATLANTIC STURGEON IN THE SOUTHERN EXTENT OF THEIR RANGE (WITHIN THE CAROLINA AND SOUTH ATLANTIC DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENTS). THE MAIN PROJECT GOAL WILL BE TO ESTIMATE THE EXTENT OF POPULATION MIXING WITHIN AND BETWEEN DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENTS FOR SUB-ADULT (600-1300 MM FL) ATLANTIC STURGEON, AS THIS LIFE HISTORY STAGE HAS DEMONSTRATED EXTENSIVE USE OF NON-NATAL RIVERS/ESTUARIES, WITH CONSIDERABLE MOVEMENTS OBSERVED AMONG SOUTHERN RIVERS. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO USE A COMBINATION OF GENETIC MIXED-STOCK ANALYSIS AND ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY TO INFORM POPULATION STRUCTURE OF ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT LISTED ATLANTIC STURGEON IN THE SOUTHERN EXTENT OF THEIR RANGE (WITHIN THE CAROLINA AND SOUTH ATLANTIC DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENTS). THE MAIN PROJECT GOAL WILL BE TO ESTIMATE THE EXTENT OF POPULATION MIXING WITHIN AND BETWEEN DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENTS FOR SUB-ADULT (600-1300 MM FL) ATLANTIC STURGEON, AS THIS LIFE HISTORY STAGE HAS DEMONSTRATED EXTENSIVE USE OF NON-NATAL RIVERS/ESTUARIES, WITH CONSIDERABLE MOVEMENTS OBSERVED AMONG SOUTHERN RIVERS. THE PROJECT WILL TAKE ADVANTAGE OF ARCHIVED TISSUE SAMPLES FROM SEVERAL MAJOR RIVER SYSTEMS IN THE CAROLINA AND SOUTH ATLANTIC DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENTS, AS WELL AS ESTABLISHED ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY ARRAYS TO TRACK SEASONAL AND ANNUAL MOVEMENTS OVER MULTIPLE YEARS. THE PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY ADDRESS THE PRIORITIES TO EXPAND AND IMPROVE GENETIC STOCK DEFINITIONS, PARTICULARLY WITHIN THE SO

THE RECIPIENT WILL CREATE A TOOL TO IDENTIFY HOTSPOTS OF OVERLAP AND POSSIBLE NON-REPORTING OF CATCH OF HIGH SEAS FLEETS FOR SEVERAL SPECIES GROUPS OF HIGH IMPORTANCE (TUNAS, BILLFISHES AND SHARKS). THEY WILL COMBINE AN UNPRECEDENTED SET OF ELECTRONIC TAGGING DATA; NOVEL TECHNOLOGY ALLOWING FOR REAL-TIME TRACKING OF HIGH SEAS FISHING EFFORTS USING VESSEL AUTOMATIC IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM, SATELLITE-DERIVED NIGHTTIME LIGHT SIGNATURES FROM VESSELS, AND A GROWING NUMBER OF NATIONAL VESSEL MONITORING SYSTEM SYSTEMS (INCLUDING OVER 5,000 VESSELS FLAGGED TO INDONESIA, CHILE, PANAMA, COSTA RICA, AND PERU); AND EXPERTISE IN FISH SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL DISTRIBUTION, FISHERIES, AND ELECTRONIC MONITORING.

NFWF WILL WORK WITH NOAA FISHERIES TO SUPPORT THE ELECTRONIC MONITORING AND REPORTING REGIONAL IMPLEMENTATION PLANS DEVELOPED BY THE FISHERIES MANAGEMENT COUNCILS TO IDENTIFY, EVALUATE, AND PRIORITIZE IMPLEMENTATION OF PROMISING ELECTRONIC TECHNOLOGIES THAT IMPROVE OUR KNOWLEDGE OF THE FISHERIES AND EMPOWER FISHERMEN AND OTHER CITIZENS TO BECOME MORE ACTIVELY INVOLVED IN THE DATA COLLECTION PROCESS. THE CURRENT APPLICATION PROPOSES TO ADMINISTER AN ELECTRONIC MONITORING AND REPORTING (EMR) GRANT PROGRAM IN 2022 THAT ADVANCES THE NOAA FISHERIES GOALS FOR HEALTHY OCEANS, SUSTAINABLE FISHERIES AND SAFE SEAFOOD FOR HEALTHY POPULATIONS AND VIBRANT COMMUNITIES BY SUPPORTING PARTNERSHIPS AND COOPERATION AMONG NOAA STAFF, REGIONAL FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCILS, COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERMEN, SERVICE PROVIDERS, NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (NGOS), UNIVERSITIES AND OTHERS. THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, NFWF WILL HELP ADVANCE THE ADOPTION OF EFFECTIVE AND PRACTICAL ELECTRONIC TECHNOLOGIES TO MO

AS AN ACTIVE MEMBER OF THE ATLANTIC LARGE WHALE DISENTANGLEMENT NETWORK (ALWDN), FWRI SHALL COOPERATE WITH NOAA FISHERIES, GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (GDNR), AND OTHER ALWDN MEMBERS IN RESPONDING TO REPORTS OF ENTANGLED WHALES, AND CARRY OUT OTHER TASKS THAT REDUCE INJURY AND MORTALITY CAUSED BY FISHERIES AND FISHING EQUIPMENT, AND THAT PROVIDE OUTREACH TO THE PUBLIC.

THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (GDNR) WILDLIFE RESOURCES DIVISION (WRD) PROPOSES TO IMPLEMENT NORTH ATLANTIC RIGHT WHALE RECOVERY EFFORTS IN THE SOUTHEAST U.S. DURING FY23 IN COOPERATION WITH THE NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE'S (NMFS) SOUTHEAST REGIONAL OFFICE (SERO), FLORIDA FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION COMMISSION (FWC), THE CLEARWATER MARINE AQUARIUM RESEARCH INSTITUTE (CMARI) AND OTHER PARTNERS. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE (1) FLYING AERIAL SURVEYS, (2) CONDUCTING BOAT SURVEYS AND WHALE BIOPSY SAMPLING, (3) OTHER RESEARCH AND MONITORING, (4) RESPONDING TO ENTANGLED, INJURED AND DEAD WHALES, (5) MITIGATING IMPACTS TO RIGHT WHALES AND THEIR HABITAT, AND (6) COOPERATING WITH NMFS TO IMPLEMENT THE NORTH ATLANTIC RIGHT WHALE RECOVERY PLAN.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO BE THE FIRST STUDY OF ITS SIZE TO EVALUATE POP-UP BUOY TECHNOLOGY AS A VIABLE ALTERNATIVE TO TRADITIONAL CRABBING GEAR WHILE REDUCING THE IMPACT OF FISHING ON MIGRATING WHALE POPULATIONS. WHILE IN THE PRODUCT RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT PHASE, FUNDING WILL SUPPORT THE FOLLOWING TASKS: 1) TEST 150 PUGET BUOY UNITS ON 5 COMMERCIAL DUNGENESS CRAB FISHING VESSELS IN CALIFORNIA STATE FISHERIES; 2) COLLECT DATA FOLLOWING KEY PERFORMANCE INDICATORS: RECOVERY RATE, OPERATING SPEED, THE AMOUNT OF TIME LINE SPENDS IN THE WATER COLUMN, AND CONSUMER FEEDBACK; AND 3) RETURN PERFORMANCE ANALYSIS TO STATE FISHERY MANAGEMENT PERSONNEL THAT PROVIDES DETAILED PERFORMANCE METRICS OF OUR SOLUTION.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO QUANTIFY THE EFFICACY OF A MODIFIED FLEXIGRID SYSTEM DESIGNED TO REDUCE JUVENILE SABLEFISH CATCHES IN THE WEST COAST GROUNDFISH BOTTOM TRAWL FISHERY.  GEAR PERFORMANCE WILL BE DIRECTLY MEASURED USING THE COVERED GEAR METHOD. MEAN SIZE-SELECTION PROPERTIES (L50, SR) WILL BE MODELED FOR SABLEFISH AND OTHER TARGET GROUNDFISHES. FIELD WORK WILL OCCUR OVER 10 FISHING DAYS ONBOARD A COMMERCIAL FISHING VESSEL. FOLLOWING GEAR TRIALS, RESULTS WILL BE PRESENTED TO FISHERS, INDUSTRY MANAGERS, AND THE PACIFIC FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL HIGHLIGHTING THE ECONOMIC AND ECOLOGICAL BENEFITS OF THE MODIFIED FLEXIGRID SYSTEM IF APPLIED TO THE FISHERY. LASTLY, THIS RESEARCH WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE MASTER'S DEGREE OF A STUDENT AT OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO IMPLEMENT AND COOPERATIVELY TEST NOVEL DETERRENTS DESIGNED TO MITIGATE SHARK DEPREDATION IN SNAPPER-GROUPER FISHERIES. INVESTIGATORS WILL ADDRESS THIS BY FULFILLING THREE MAJOR OBJECTIVES OVER THE COURSE OF THIS STUDY: 1) DEVELOP FEASIBLE RECREATIONAL GEAR CONFIGURATIONS THAT INCORPORATE SHARK DETERRENTS; 2) TEST DETERRENTS WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO EXAMINE PERFORMANCE AND BARRIERS TO ADOPTION; AND 3) DISSEMINATE RESULTS TO STAKEHOLDERS INVOLVED IN SNAPPER-GROUPER FISHERIES.

THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE LONGFIN SQUID FISHERY DATA COLLECTION OPPORTUNITIES RELATIVE TO TEDS AND LONGFIN SQUID RETENTION RESULTS WHEN UTILIZING THEM IN RESPONSE TO PROPOSED REGULATIONS TO ADOPT TEDS INTO THIS FISHERY. THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT AN EXTENSIVE AT-SEA EVALUATION OF 2 TED DESIGNS. THE OUTREACH COMPONENT OF THIS PROGRAM WILL UTILIZE 2 WORKSHOPS TO JOIN THE COMMERCIAL FISHING INDUSTRY, SCIENTIFIC RESEARCHERS, AND FISHERIES MANAGEMENT SECTORS TO SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONSERVATION ENGINEERING DEVICES TO MINIMIZE TURTLE BYCATCH AND REDUCE MORTALITIES WHILE MAINTAINING A SUSTAINABLE AND VIABLE INSHORE LONGFIN SQUID FISHERY. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES MULTIPLE NOAA COLLABORATIONS AND UTILIZES A PROJECT ADVISORY COMMITTEE THAT WILL GUIDE THE PROGRAM TO HAVE A HIGH LIKELIHOOD OF SUCCESS.

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THE PROPOSED STUDY IS TO IMPROVE THE SURVIVABILITY OF SCALLOPED HAMMERHEADS DISCARDED IN THE US ATLANTIC PELAGIC LONGLINE FISHERY (PLF). THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY ADDRESSING TWO PRIMARY OBJECTIVES, INCLUDING (1) QUANTIFY POST-RELEASE MORTALITY (PRM) OF SCALLOPED HAMMERHEADS IN THE US PLF USING SATELLITE TELEMETRY AND (2) MODEL THE EFFECTS OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, FISHING AND HANDLING PRACTICES, AND BIOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS (E.G. SEX, SIZE) ON PRM TO IDENTIFY BEST FISHING PRACTICES THAT MAXIMIZE POST-RELEASE SURVIVAL. WORK WILL INCLUDE DEPLOYMENT OF 50 POP-OFF SATELLITE ARCHIVAL TAGS (PSATS) TO TRACK SURVIVAL RATES OF SCALLOPED HAMMERHEADS FOR UP TO 28 DAYS FOLLOWING CAPTURE WITH STANDARD FISHERY PRACTICES IN THE PLF. RESULTS WILL BE DISSEMINATED TO RELEVANT POLICY MAKERS AND SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY MEMBERS.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEMONSTRATE THAT ROPELESS FISHING CAN BE CONDUCTED AT A SCALE THAT IS COMMENSURATE WITH TYPICAL FISHING OPERATIONS WHILE PROVIDING RISK REDUCTION FOR MARINE MAMMAL ENTANGLEMENT AND AN ALTERNATIVE TO TIME-AREA CLOSURES. THE WORK WILL COMPRISE FOUR TASKS INCLUDING (1) ESTABLISHING A PATHWAY FOR LARGE-SCALE UTILIZATION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF ROPELESS FISHING FOR DUNGENESS CRAB FISHERS IN CALIFORNIA; (2) PROVIDING THE NECESSARY OUTREACH, EQUIPMENT, TRAINING AND AT-SEA TRIALS TO DEVELOP AND VERIFY THE REQUIRED LEVEL OF ROPELESS FISHING EXPERTISE FOR KEY EARLY ADOPTERS; (3) DEMONSTRATING AND DOCUMENTING THAT ROPELESS FISHING CAN BE SUCCESSFULLY SCALED TO A LEVEL THAT IS REPRESENTATIVE OF LARGE-SCALE ADOPTION FOR PARTICIPATING FISHERS, AND (4) USING THE RESULTS TO IDENTIFY FURTHER TECHNOLOGY IMPROVEMENTS, DEFINE REMAINING BARRIERS TO IMPLEMENTATION, EDUCATE THE FISHING COMMUNITY ON THE OUTCOMES, AND RECOMMEND A PATH FORWARD FOR ROPELESS FISHING THAT CAN BE SUPPOR

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO DEVELOP A REMOTELY DEPLOYED OFFSHORE LOBSTER TRAP RETRIEVAL SYSTEM AT A LOW COST THAT IS CAPABLE OF INTEGRATING SEVERAL ACOUSTIC COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS FOR USE IN OFFSHORE LOBSTER FISHERIES. THE RESEARCHERS WILL MANUFACTURE 15-30 ROPELESS UNITS DESIGNED TO OPERATE IN THE DEPTHS AND PRESSURES CHARACTERISTIC OF OFFSHORE FISHING, WITH INTEGRATED ACOUSTICS, AND TEST THE UNITS AT SEA WITH COMMERCIAL FISHERS IN MA AND ME.

THE PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO QUANTIFY THE LEVEL OF POST-RELEASE MORTALITY FOR THE COMMERCIAL (>185 CM CFL) ATLANTIC BLUEFIN TUNA CATCH AND RELEASE FISHERY LOCATED OFF NEW ENGLAND. THIS WILL INCLUDE ESTIMATING MORTALITY FOR AGE CLASSES BETWEEN ~7-20+ YEARS OLD. FORTY-FIVE ELECTRONIC SATELLITE SURVIVAL TAGS (WILDLIFE COMPUTERS, USA) WILL BE APPLIED TO COMMERCIAL SIZE (>185 CM CURVED FORK LENGTH) ATLANTIC BLUEFIN TUNA RELEASED FROM CHARTER AND PRIVATE VESSELS PARTICIPATING IN CATCH AND RELEASE ACTIVITIES IN NEW ENGLAND BETWEEN JUNE AND OCTOBER. VARIABLES WILL BE RECORDED AT EACH CAPTURE EVENT, POST-RELEASE SURVIVAL WILL BE ASSESSED, AND RESULTING SURVIVAL DATA WILL BE ANALYZED. MODEL RESULTS WILL ALSO CLEARLY IDENTIFY THOSE SPECIFIC ASPECTS OF THE CAPTURE EVENT THAT CAUSE MORTALITY AND ASSIST WITH THE DESIGN OF BEST PRACTICE RECOMMENDATIONS OR FISHING REGULATIONS THAT FUNCTION TO REDUCE MORTALITY.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO IMPROVE THE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW "FULLY FORMED" REDUCED BREAKING STRENGTH ROPES OR WEAK CONTRIVANCES PLACED AT DIFFERENT POINTS ALONG A VERTICAL LINE IN CRUSTACEAN POT GEAR AFFECTS THE OUTCOME OF WHALE ENTANGLEMENTS, ESPECIALLY WHERE AND HOW QUICKLY VERTICAL LINE BREAKS OCCUR WHEN A WHALE COLLIDES WITH THEM. INVESTIGATORS WILL FURTHER DEVELOP AND THEN USE A COMPUTER MODEL DEVELOPED IN ORCAFLEX TO SIMULATE WHALE ENTANGLEMENTS IN FIXED-FISHING GEAR USING DIFFERENT WEAK (1700LBF) ROPES AND ROPE CONTRIVANCES. THIS WILL INCLUDE ADDING AN OPEN MOUTH COMPONENT TO THE WHALE MODEL, RUNNING ENTANGLEMENT SCENARIOS WITH DIFFERENT WHALE BEHAVIORS AND GEAR CONFIGURATIONS, EXAMINING THE EFFECT OF DIFFERENT ROPE ELASTICITIES, CONDUCTING AT-SEA TESTING TO GROUND-TRUTH OUR MODEL, INFORMING THE PERFORMANCE OF NMFS-APPROVED WEAK GEAR, AND PROVIDING THE AGENCY WITH DETAILS ABOUT CHANGE IN ENTANGLEMENT RISK WITH DIFFERENT WEAK ROPE CONFIGURATIONS AND PROPERTIES FOR INT

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO EVALUATE FISH-GEAR INTERACTIONS TO DEVELOP BYCATCH REDUCTION MEASURES FOR THREATENED GREEN STURGEON THAT ARE CAUGHT AS BYCATCH IN THE CALIFORNIA HALIBUT (CAHB) TRAWL FISHERY OUT OF SAN FRANCISCO AND HALF MOON BAY. INVESTIGATORS WILL OBTAIN VIDEO FOOTAGE OF FISH-GEAR INTERACTIONS ACROSS MULTIPLE FISHING VESSELS, SEASONS, AND YEARS (WHEN COMBINED WITH OUR PILOT STUDY), CHARACTERIZE THE BEHAVIOR OF GREEN STURGEON, OTHER NON-TARGET SPECIES, AND CA HALIBUT IN RESPONSE TO THE NET; AND DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS AND NEXT STEPS IN COLLABORATION WITH THE FISHERMEN, CDFW, NMFS, AND OTHER MANAGEMENT PARTNERS.

THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES BREP PRIORITY 2 BY ACCELERATING ADOPTION OF ACTIVE SELECTION BYCATCH REDUCTION SYSTEMS AND IMPROVING THEIR USE THROUGH EXPERIENCE AND FAMILIARITY, WHILE CONTINUING TO DEVELOP THE UNDERLYING TECHNOLOGY. THIS SYSTEM WAS DEVELOPED UNDER A RECENTLY COMPLETED BREP PROJECT.  INVESTIGATORS WILL BUILD AND PREPARE FIVE ACTSEL SYSTEMS, AND PROVIDE THEM TO TRAWLERS FOR USE DURING ROUTINE FISHING OPERATIONS, ACTSEL BRIDGE-NET COMMUNICATIONS WILL BE UPGRADED FROM ONE-WAY BINARY SIGNALS (CIRCUIT SWITCHING) TO TWO-WAY SERIAL COMMUNICATION, ALLOWING MORE FLEXIBILITY AND FEEDBACK ON REEL POSITIONS AND BATTERY POWER, AND BEST-MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR ACTSEL WILL BE COLLECTED AND COMMUNICATED FOR USE AND LESSONS-LEARNED FROM AT-SEA DEPLOYMENTS.

THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE MARINE MAMMAL PROTECTION ACT (MMPA) AND ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) TO REDUCE AND SIGNIFICANTLY LOWER LEVELS (APPROACHING ZERO) OF MORTALITY AND SERIOUS INJURY RATE OF MARINE MAMMALS OCCURRING IN COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FIXED GEAR FISHING OPERATIONS BY REMOVING PERSISTENT VERTICAL LINES WITH SMELTS ROPELESS LIFT-BAG TECHNOLOGY INCLUDING THE LOBSTER, CRAB AND GILLNET RAFT . THIS WILL ALLOW FISHERMEN TO FIND, VIEW AND RECOVER SMELTS ROPELESS LIFT BAG GEAR, AND SHOW FISHERIES ENFORCEMENT HOW TO VIEW AND REGULATE ROPELESS GEAR. SMELTS WILL WORK ON TRIALS THAT DEMONSTRATE REPEATABLE RESULTS AND SHOW THAT A SUITE OF DATA WILL BE NEEDED TO ACCURATELY MARK ROPELESS GEAR IN AND OUT OF THE OCEAN. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO PRODUCE A NOVEL TAG ANCHOR AND POWER-ASSISTED DELIVERY DEVICE FOR USE IN DEPLOYING TOWED ELECTRONIC TAGS ON PACIFIC LEATHERBACKS THAT INTERACT WITH LONGLINE AND OTHER FISHERIES. THIS TAG DEPLOYMENT SYSTEM WILL ENABLE TAGGING LEATHERBACKS SAFELY, AT-SEA TO STUDY THEIR POST-RELEASE SURVIVORSHIP AND FILL SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION GAPS FOR ECOSYSTEM BASED FISHERY MANAGEMENT. INVESTIGATORS WILL DESIGN AND PRODUCE FINAL PROTOTYPES OF 1) A CUSTOM TAG ANCHOR, AND 2) A POWER-ASSISTED DELIVERY DEVICE (PADD). FINAL DESIGNS WILL BE TESTED ON LEATHERBACK CARAPACE SAMPLES AS ESTABLISHED IN PRIOR WORK, TISSUE SAMPLES WILL BE EVALUATED FOR CARAPACE FRACTURES AND DAMAGES TO UNDERLYING CONNECTIVE TISSUE, IMPLANTATION FORCE MEASUREMENTS WILL FEED INTO THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE POWER-ASSISTED DELIVERY DEVICE, AND RESULTS WILL BE PROVIDED TO NOAA RESEARCHERS AND PREPARED FOR PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATION. SIX SETS OF DELIVERY DEVICES AND ANCHORS WILL BE MANUFACTURED AND PROVIDED TO NOAA RESEARC

THIS PROJECT ADVANCES UNDERSTANDING OF GENETIC IMPLICATIONS OF LARGE SCALE RESTORATION VIA LARVAL PROPAGATION, A TOOL THAT IS INCREASINGLY EMPLOYED IN RESTORATION FOR ELKHORN CORAL AS WELL AS STONY CORAL TISSUE LOSS DISEASE AFFECTED SPECIES.  APPLICATION OF RESULTS OBTAINED CAN LOWER GENETIC RISKS AND IMPROVE THE SUCCESS OF RESTORATION EFFORTS FOR THESE KEY ARCHITECTURAL SPECIES OF CARIBBEAN REEF SYSTEMS, THUS AIDING IN RECOVERY OF LISTED SPECIES, PROTECTING AND ENHANCING BIODIVERSITY AND REEF FISHERIES HABITAT.

THIS SUITE OF APPLIED RESEARCH COMPONENTS TAKES A FARM-CENTERED APPROACH TO ADDRESS EXXON VALDEZ OIL SPILL TRUSTEE COUNCIL RESTORATION, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, OUTREACH, ADMINISTRATION, AND DATA MANAGEMENT INTERESTS THAT OVERLAP TOP PRIORITIES IDENTIFIED BY STAKEHOLDERS AND THE ALASKA MARICULTURE DEVELOPMENT PLAN DEVELOPED BY THE ALASKA GOVERNOR'S MARICULTURE TASK FORCE. RESULTS WILL INFORM SHELLFISH AND SEAWEED PRODUCTION, WITH FARMERS AS FULL PARTICIPANTS IN THE RESEARCH. TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER AND TRAINING FOR NEW AND EXISTING FARMERS WILL INVESTIGATE FARM DESIGNS AND SUPPORT INDUSTRY GROWTH, BRINGING GREEN JOBS AND ECONOMIC DIVERSIFICATION TO COASTAL COMMUNITIES IN THE OIL SPILL AFFECTED AREA. THE GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO DEVELOP AN IMPROVED MEASUREMENT OF ABUNDANCE FOR WESTERN BLUEFIN TUNA (BFT) THAT ACCOUNT FOR THE EFFECTS OF CHANGING OCEAN CONDITIONS. THE PROPOSED ACTIVITIES WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH FISHERY STAKEHOLDERS TO DEVELOP MODELS OF BFT CATCH PER UNIT AND EVALUATE ITS INFLUENCE ON THE STOCK ASSESSMENT.

THE INTERNATIONAL COMMISSION FOR THE CONSERVATION OF ATLANTIC TUNAS (ICCAT) IS CONSIDERING A TRANSITION TO AN EMPIRICAL MANAGEMENT PROCEDURE FOR DETERMINING TOTAL ALLOWABLE CATCH, BUT OCCASIONAL STOCK ASSESSMENTS WILL CONTINUE TO BE APPLIED FOR STATUS DETERMINATION AND EVALUATING PERFORMANCE OF THE MANAGEMENT PROCEDURE FOR AVOIDING OVERFISHING AND REBUILDING (ICCAT 2021). EASTERN AND WESTERN STOCKS OF ATLANTIC BLUEFIN TUNA ARE ASSESSED BY THE USING VIRTUAL POPULATION ANALYSIS AND STOCK SYNTHESIS APPLICATIONS (ICCAT 2020, 2021). SIMILAR PROBLEMS WERE ENCOUNTERED IN THE 2021 UPDATED ASSESSMENT OF THE WESTERN ATLANTIC STOCK. THIS PROPOSAL IS INTENDED TO COLLABORATE WITH SEFSC SCIENTISTS AND OTHER ICCAT SCIENTISTS TO ADVANCE

STURGEONS ARE THE MOST IMPERILED FAMILY OF FISHES WITH MANY TAXA CONSIDERED ENDANGERED FROM OVERFISHING, HABITAT LOSS AND OTHER IMPEDIMENTS TO RECOVERY. CENTRAL TO THEIR RECOVERY IS AN UNDERSTANDING OF POPULATION DYNAMICS INCLUDING JUVENILE ABUNDANCE AND SPAWNING RUN SIZES. UNFORTUNATELY, MANY TRADITIONAL APPROACHES TO ESTIMATING ABUNDANCE ARE INTRACTABLE WITH ATLANTIC STURGEON DUE TO THEIR DEPRESSED NUMBERS AND LOGISTICAL CONSTRAINTS INHERENT WITH SAMPLING LARGE RIVERS. AT PRESENT, SCANT INFORMATION IS AVAILABLE ON ESTIMATES OF ADULT ABUNDANCE FOR MOST RIVERS. THIS FULLY INTEGRATED MULTI-STATE PROPOSAL EMPLOYS OUR RECENTLY PUBLISHED METHODOLOGY TO INCORPORATE HYDROACOUSTIC SURVEYS AND EXISTING ACOUSTIC RECEIVER NETWORKS TO ESTIMATE NUMBER OF SPAWNERS WHICH ARE COUPLED WITH TWO WELL ESTABLISHED RIVER-RESIDENT JUVENILE SURVEYS TO FORECAST RECOVERY OF ADULTS IN THE DELAWARE AND HUDSON RIVERS. ENTANGLEMENTS OF ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT LISTED BALEEN WHALES IN FIXED GEAR FISHERIES ALONG THE US WEST COAST HAVE BEEN ELEVATED OVER HISTORICAL LEVELS SINCE 2014, SOMETIMES EXCEEDING BIOLOGICALLY SUSTAINABLE LEVELS UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND THE MARINE MAMMAL PROTECTION ACT. CONFIRMED ENTANGLEMENTS OF ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT LISTED LEATHERBACK SEA TURTLES IN WEST COAST FIXED GEAR HAVE ALSO OCCURRED IN RECENT YEARS. A POTENTIAL MITIGATION STRATEGY TO REDUCE WHALE AND TURTLE ENTANGLEMENT RATES IS TO REDUCE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL CO-OCCURRENCE OF THESE SPECIES AND FISHING GEAR. THE NORTH PACIFIC MARINE HEATWAVE, THE MOST SEVERE AND PERSISTENT MARINE HEATWAVE IN RECENT HISTORY, WHICH BEGAN IN 2014 AND CONTINUED AT VARYING LEVELS INTO AT LEAST 2020, RESULTED IN SIGNIFICANT AND WIDE-SPREAD PERTURBATION OF THE GULF OF ALASKA ECOSYSTEM. OUR PROPOSED STUDY WILL ADDRESS HOW CLIMATE CHANGE MAY AFFECT RECOVERY OF THE WESTERN DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT OF STELLER SEA LIONS, INCLUDING EMERGING THREATS FROM BIOTOXINS, NOVEL DISEASES AND SUDDEN AND LARGE SHIFTS IN THE PREY BASE, WHILE ALSO ADDRESSING SEVERAL CRITICAL DATA GAPS (E.G., LACK OF RECENT DIET INFORMATION AND LIMITED INFORMATION ON ADULT FEMALE FORAGING AREAS AND HEALTH). THE SUBSISTENCE HARVEST OF ICE SEALS (RINGED, BEARDED, SPOTTED AND RIBBON) PROVIDES THOUSANDS OF POUNDS OF EDIBLE MEAT AND OIL ANNUALLY, A SIGNIFICANT SOURCE OF FOOD FOR PEOPLE IN MORE THAN 55 COASTAL COMMUNITIES IN ALASKA. DOCUMENTING THE MAGNITUDE OF THE HARVEST IS A BASIC MANAGEMENT REQUIREMENT AND IMPORTANT FOR UNDERSTANDING SUBSISTENCE NEEDS. ALTHOUGH ALL FOUR ICE SEAL SPECIES ARE CURRENTLY ABUNDANT IN ALASKAN WATERS, CONCERNS OVER THE IMPACT OF PROJECTED SEA ICE LOSS LED TO LISTING RINGED AND BEARDED SEALS AS THREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN 2012. NO RECOVERY OBJECTIVES HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED FOR RINGED OR BEARDED SEALS; HOWEVER, CONTINUED DOCUMENTATION OF THE HARVEST REMAINS AN IMPORTANT COMPONENT OF THEIR MANAGEMENT. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES CRITICAL DATA GAPS BY DOCUMENTING AND REPORTING THE CURRENT SUBSISTENCE HARVEST OF ICE SEALS AT COMMUNITIES THAT HAVE HISTORICALLY HARVESTED THE MOST SEALS REGIONALLY. MOST OF THESE HIGH-PRIORITY COMMUNITIES HAVE NOT BEEN SURVEYED

LARGE-SCALE HABITAT MODIFICATIONS TO FRESHWATER RIVER SYSTEMS HAVE HINDERED RECOVERY OF ATLANTIC STURGEON (ACIPENSER OXYRINCHUS OXYRINCHUS) AND SHORTNOSE STURGEON (ACIPENSER BREVIROSTRUM) STOCKS THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE. A MYRIAD OF ANTHROPOGENIC IMPACTS, INCLUDING CHANNELIZATION, DAM INSTALLATION, WATER MANAGEMENT, AND POLLUTION NEGATIVELY AFFECT REPRODUCTION AND RECRUITMENT. ADDITIONALLY, ALTHOUGH THEY ARE PROTECTED FROM HARVEST, ADULTS OF BOTH SPECIES ARE STILL CAPTURED AS BYCATCH IN OTHER FISHERIES.  THE IMPACTS OF THESE HUMAN ACTIVITIES  AND THEIR RELATIVE DEGREES OF INFLUENCE  VARY AMONG RIVER SYSTEMS AND AMONG DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENTS, AS DOES THE DEGREE TO WHICH STATUS AND LIFE HISTORIES OF ATLANTIC STURGEON AND SHORTNOSE STURGEON ARE UNDERSTOOD.  THESE KNOWLEDGE GAPS CREATE CHALLENGES FOR MANAGING ATLANTIC STURGEON AND SHORTNOSE STURGEON RECOVERY THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE. THROUGH THIS RESTORATION PROJECT, THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF CHENEGA WILL ADDRESS SEVEN ABANDONED VESSELS LOCATED IN THE VILLAGES HARBOR. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PROJECT PLANNING, ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENTS, REGULATORY COMPLIANCE, CONTRACTING FOR VESSEL REMOVAL AND TRANSPORT SERVICES, AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH. BY REMOVING THESE VESSELS, THE NEARSHORE AND INTERTIDAL ECOSYSTEM WILL BE RESTORED AND PROTECTED FROM THE RISK OF FUTURE POLLUTION EVENTS THAT MAY HAVE RESULTED FROM THE ABANDONED VESSELS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL BARRIERS TO THE VILLAGES ECONOMIC RECOVERY FROM THE EXXON VALDEZ OIL SPILL WILL BE REMOVED.

IN THE THREE DECADES SINCE THE EXXON VALDEZ OIL SPILL, IT HAS BEEN RECOGNIZED THAT FULL RECOVERY FROM THE SPILL WILL TAKE DECADES AND REQUIRES LONG-TERM MONITORING OF BOTH THE INJURED RESOURCES AND OTHER FACTORS TO DETERMINE WHAT MAY INHIBIT THE SYSTEM FROM RECOVERING TO PRE-SPILL CONDITIONS. THIS REQUIRES AN INTEGRATED MONITORING PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES INFORMATION ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL DRIVERS, PELAGIC, AND INTERTIDAL COMPONENTS OF THE MARINE ECOSYSTEM. THE PROGRAM IS BUILT WITH A VARIETY OF COMPONENT PROJECTS THAT ADDRESS THE MONITORING OBJECTIVE OF THE PROGRAM. THE MONITORING IS COMPLEMENTED BY SEPARATELY FUNDED SCIENCE SYNTHESIS TO INCREASE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE GULF OF ALASKA ECOSYSTEM PROCESSES AND FUN

THIS PROPOSAL IS TO PROVIDE SPONSORSHIP FOR THE NATIONAL MITIGATION AND ECOSYSTEM BANKING CONFERENCE. THE NATIONAL MITIGATION AND ECOSYSTEM BANKING CONFERENCE IS AN ANNUAL CONFERENCE SCHEDULED DURING THE SPRING OF EACH YEAR IN DIFFERENT PARTS OF THE COUNTRY. SPONSORSHIP OF THIS CONFERENCE WILL PRODUCE THE ANNUAL NATIONAL MITIGATION AND ECOSYSTEM BANKING CONFERENCE IN 2022, 2023, 2024, 2025, AND 2026. THE NATIONAL MITIGATION AND ECOSYSTEM BANKING CONFERENCE WAS FOUNDED IN 1997 WITH A DIVERSE STEERING COMMITTEE OF LEADERS IN THE REGULATORY, BANKING, AND ENVIRONMENTAL COMMUNITY. IT IS THE FIRST, AND ONLY, NATIONAL CONFERENCE FOCUSED ON MITIGATION, CONSERVATION AND ECOSYSTEM BANKING TO PROTECT WETLANDS, ENDANGERED SPECIES, AND OTHER NATURAL RESOURCES. IT BRINGS TOGETHER KEY STAKEHOLDERS TO EXPLORE POLICY AND PRACTICE, SHARE SUCCESSES AND FAILURES, AND LEARN ABOUT TRENDS, SCIENCE AND EMERGING MARKETS. THE CONFERENCE PRESENTS CURRENT AND TIMELY CONTENT AND DIALOGUE ON IMPORTANT ISSUES THROUG

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A FEASIBLE PROCESS TO EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF DYNAMIC SPATIAL FISHERY CLOSURES FOR PELAGIC SPECIES. TIME-AREA CLOSURES ARE A COMMON FISHERIES MANAGEMENT STRATEGY DESIGNED TO RESTRICT ACCESS TO A GIVEN AREA WITH THE GOAL OF REDUCING INTERACTIONS WITH TARGET SPECIES. OFTEN, THESE CLOSURES ARE SMALL IN AREA AND STATIC OVER TIME. THE BENEFITS OF SMALL, STATIC AREAS TO MOBILE, PELAGIC SPECIES ARE MINIMAL AND RECENT EFFORTS HAVE SUGGESTED MOVING TO LARGER, DYNAMIC CLOSURES. TO DEFINE SUCH CLOSURES, SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS NEED DYNAMIC MAPS OF THE SPECIES INTERACTIONS WITH FISHERIES TO DELIMIT AREAS OF HIGH RISK. HOWEVER, THIS SHIFT IN APPROACH DOES NOT ESTABLISH THE EFFICACY OF THE TIME-AREA CLOSURE. TO ESTABLISH EFFICACY, SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS NEED INFORMATION ON THE POTENTIAL RISK OF INTERACTIONS IN THE FUTURE, WHICH REQUIRES UNDERSTANDING HOW FISHING ACTIVITY WILL CHANGE AFTER A CLOSURE, HOW THE SPECIES' DISTRIBUTION MIGHT CHANGE IN THE FUTURE, AND HOW

THIS STUDY SEEKS TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL METHODS FOR PROTECTING HOOK CAPTURED FISH FROM WHALE DEPREDATION AND TO DEVELOP AND FIELD-TEST SEVERAL SIMPLE LOW-COST CATCH-PROTECTION DESIGNS THAT CAN BE DEPLOYED EFFECTIVELY USING CURRENT LONGLINE FISHING TECHNIQUES. PROPOSED WORK ENTAILS CONDUCTING A WORKSHOP WITH INDUSTRY (AFFECTED FISHERS, GEAR RESEARCHERS, SCIENTISTS) TO IDENTIFY METHODS TO PROTECT FISHERY CATCHES FROM DEPREDATION. THE TOP TWO OR THREE CATCH PROTECTION DESIGN OUTCOMES FROM THE WORKSHOP WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO FUNCTIONAL PROTOTYPES AND FIELD TESTED IN LONGLINE SEA TRIALS TARGETING FLATFISH. THIS PROJECT WILL FURTHER DEFINE AND DEVELOP PREVIOUSLY IDENTIFIED HIGH PRIORITY WORK THAT CAN BREAK THE REWARD CYCLE OF DEPREDATION BEHAVIOR AND THEREBY SUPPRESS ITS PREVALENCE. IT WILL IDENTIFY STRATEGIES TO PROTECT ALREADY CAPTURED FISH IN COST EFFECTIVE MANNERS THAT ARE COMPATIBLE WITH CURRENTLY EMPLOYED HOOK AND LINE FISHING PRACTICES. EASE OF DEPLOYMENT AND COST EFFECTIVENESS WILL BE CRITICAL TO ADOPTION BY FISHING FLEETS TO MITIGATE THIS DEVELOPING CHALLENGE. SUCCESSFUL DEVELOPMENT OF DEPREDATION MITIGATION STRATEGIES WILL SAVE THE INDUSTRY MONEY, REDUCE WASTAGE IN THE FISHERY, AND ASSURE MANAGERS THAT CATCH RECORDS ARE ACCURATELY CAPTURING REMOVALS.
